What exactly do you mean by value-based pricing? BRENNAN: I guess value-based pricing, in my mind, is the opposite of commodity pricing. Commodity pricing is the idea that, â€œHey, I'm a Ruby developer therefore I have a market rate, therefore my acceptable rate that I charge my clients is x.â€ Value-based pricing is really where you donâ€™t put the focus on you and your industry or you and your craft; instead, you're focusing on the client. You're focusing on â€œWhat solution am I solving? What are the implications of the solution being delivered?â€ And how can I anchor that against a price that makes sense to me and my client. So itâ€™s really just getting away from the idea, the kind of the race to the bottom of â€“ well, I do x and x is worth y. CHUCK: I like that idea. My method is really just figuring out, â€œWhat do they need tomorrow to look like and how can we put something together that gets them closer to that?â€ versus just reacting to technical requirements. I think with us having these constraints, with me having these constraints with my clients, it was just a lot easier for me to make sure that the work I was doing was work that would yield a return on investment in the future, right? Everything was anchored by â€œIs this getting us closer to that goal, that problem that we need solved that we had identified early on in the engagement?â€ Yeah, we could build the best product in the world and, whether it be environmental factors, or industry factors, or just the client not shipping it or not putting effort into it â€“ I mean, we can only do our best, as long as the direction that you're aiming in is always kinda centered by this constraint, by this outcome that needs to be accomplished. You're gonna be much better off than the typical person whoâ€™s just kind of like, building stuff, without knowing why they're building. CHUCK: Yeah, that makes sense. Did you ever run into a situation where you wished you had, instead of value-based pricing, you would have gone with the commodity pricing? BRENNAN: Kind of. BRENNAN: We all hate getting NDAs, right? Like when your client says, â€œHey, sign my non-disclosure before I talk to you about the project.â€ We all hate that. I hate it. A lot of people with value-based pricing, I think, incorrectly assume that the goal is, â€œOkay. So you're gonna make them 100,000, subtract a few dollars and price that.â€ I donâ€™t use it; I donâ€™t think that you should be always choosing a price thatâ€™s a little lower or somewhere in between what the potential payoff is for them.
